meeting_annotations.speaker: George Weinstock
meeting_annotations.transcript: And that's what gets selected for. So you, you know, it's it's some kind of partnership like that. meeting_annotations.speaker: Kaiwong (Calvin) Ye
meeting_annotations.transcript: Yes, this is actually incredibly exciting for me because I'm working on similar thing. meeting_annotations.speaker: Lisa Osborne
meeting_annotations.transcript: As far as I know, it's really hard to make direct comparisons between mouse microbiota and human microbiota. You might see some general trends that hold up. SFB colonizes mice, but it doesn't colonize people. You do have similar or microbes that attach to the intestinal epithelium and induce a similar response in people, but it's not the same strain. So looking at fila or like looking at taxonomic levels across human and mice isn't always particularly informative.

There's going to be a lot of microbiomes appearing as the host genetics evolves and changes from time to time and uh, um, you know, that's sort of a 20,000 foot hand waving thing that says there's coevolution, but it, you know, it's so what? What's the, you know, is the microbiome this major mediator of phenotypes and animals that are being selected for as they evolve, uh, and it's, you know, like the the dark matter of evolution or something like that, uh, the the missing heritability, you know, all that kind of stuff, it's really the microbiome because you're you're not looking at the mediator, you're just trying to connect things that are not directly connected or what's going on.
